comments.body: Invocations of anything that isn't an Ansible module, such as ansible and ansible-playbook on the controller.

comments.body: I've never seen `print(file=...)` before, should we still be printing a byte string or should it be a native string?

This change just standardizes on the new `to_bytes` function instead of using `encode()` to do the same thing. I was trying to minimize the amount of encoding related changes in this PR that may actually change behavior, other than to fix issues I was encountering during testing.

I'd like to do more encoding cleanup in a follow up PR, including taking another look at this. I just didn't want to do it all at once.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +653,657 @@
        if sys.version_info[0] == 2:
            message = to_bytes(message)

        print(message, file=fd)

comments.body: Is it worthwhile taking a copy of the text utils we already have in Ansible. They have a `nonstring` option to define things like what to do when a None object is being encoded.
The optional versions exist so that the PEP 484 type hints are accurate. The optional versions may return `None`, while the non-optional versions do not.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +84,88 @@

def to_optional_bytes(value, errors='strict'):  # type: (t.Optional[t.AnyStr], str) -> t.Optional[bytes]
    """Return the given value as bytes encoded using UTF-8 if not already bytes, or None if the value is None."""
    return None if value is None else to_bytes(value, errors)
